content:
The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to give the Secretary authority to establish specific time periods for retailers to accept and redeem coupons under the Food Stamp Program. Additionally, regulations can be issued to prevent stores with integrity issues from reapplying for approval based on the severity of their infractions. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to allow the Secretary to verify eligibility by requesting income and tax documents from retail food stores. Additionally, regulations may require stores to provide written authorization for tax verification and obtain corroborating documentation. There is also a provision for a waiting period for stores that initially fail to meet authorization criteria. Sec. 104 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to prohibit retail food stores or wholesale food concerns from reapplying for approval to accept and redeem coupons for six months if their initial application is denied. Sec. 105 is amended to establish criteria for violations and the suspension or disqualification of stores based on evidence such as on-site investigations or inconsistent redemption data. The amendment grants authority to suspend stores that violate program requirements, pending review. The amendment allows for the suspension of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns found to have violated program requirements, with the suspension coinciding with a review period. The Secretary is not liable for any lost sales during the suspension or disqualification period. The amendment allows for the suspension of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns for violating program requirements, with the suspension remaining in effect during any review process. The Secretary is not responsible for lost sales during the suspension or disqualification period. The amendment allows for the disqualification of retailers who are disqualified from the WIC program, with the disqualification period matching that of the WIC Program. Additionally, it permits the permanent debarment of retailers who intentionally submit falsified applications. The amendment allows for permanent disqualification of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns that knowingly submit false information in their application to accept and redeem food stamps. This disqualification remains in effect pending administrative and judicial review. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include civil forfeiture for violations involving food stamp benefits valued at $5,000 or more. Any benefits or property linked to the violation can be forfeited to the United States under this new provision. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 now allows for criminal forfeiture for violations related to food stamp benefits worth $5,000 or more. Convicted individuals must forfeit benefits, property obtained from the violation, and any property used in the commission of the violation to the United States. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for criminal forfeiture for violations related to food stamp benefits worth $5,000 or more. All food stamp benefits and property subject to forfeiture shall be governed by specific sections of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. The Secretary may prescribe rules and regulations to carry out this subsection. Expanded authority for sharing information provided by retailers. Sec. 110 amends the Social Security Act and Internal Revenue Code to include State government officers and employees with law enforcement responsibilities and State agencies administering the WIC program in information sharing. The Social Security Act and Internal Revenue Code are amended to include State government officers and employees with law enforcement responsibilities and State agencies administering the WIC program in information sharing. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include expanded definitions of coupons and doubled penalties for violating program requirements. Additionally, mandatory claims collection methods are established. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include expanded definitions of coupons and doubled penalties for violating program requirements. Mandatory claims collection methods are established, including refunds of Federal taxes as authorized by 31 U.S.C. 3720A. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code will be effective from October 1, 1995. TITLE III--IMPLEMENTATION AND EFFECTIVE DATES

Sec. 301. The provisions of this Act shall become effective and be implemented on the date of enactment.
